message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of Horner syndrome, which can be caused by several conditions, including lung tumors. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to perform a CT scan of the chest to rule out any pathology. The other options are not relevant to the current scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which can be caused by various underlying conditions. A CT scan of the chest is the most appropriate next step in management to identify any underlying pathology, such as lung cancer or mediastinal tumor, that can cause Horner syndrome. Rapid plasma reagin and anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are not relevant in this case. Applanation tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure and is not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of Horner’s syndrome, which can be caused by the presence of a tumor or lesion in the chest, leading to interruption of the sympathetic nerve supply. CT scan of the chest is the most appropriate next step in management to identify any such underlying cause. Options B and D are not relevant to the patient’s presentation, and applanation tonometry would not provide any useful information in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Horner syndrome, which is caused by damage to the sympathetic nervous system. This could be due to the patient’s history of smoking, but further imaging is needed to rule out other potential causes such as lung cancer. Therefore, a CT scan of the chest would be the most appropriate next step in management to investigate potential causes of the patient’s Horner syndrome. Applanation tonometry can measure intraocular pressure, but it is not relevant in this case. Rapid plasma reagin and anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are used in diagnosing syphilis and myasthenia gravis, respectively, and are not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with Horner’s syndrome, which can indicate a serious underlying condition. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of Horner syndrome, possibly caused by lung cancer. A CT scan of the chest is the most appropriate next step to identify any potential lung pathology. Applanation tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure and is not relevant in this scenario. Rapid plasma reagin is a test for syphilis, which is not relevant in this case. Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are used to diagnose myasthenia gravis, which is also not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the unequal pupils and drooping eyelid, suggest a diagnosis of Horner syndrome, which can be caused by various underlying conditions such as tumors, spinal cord injury, or other nerve damage. A CT scan of the chest can help identify whether there is an underlying cause such as lung cancer. The other options, such as applanation tonometry, are not relevant to the diagnosis of Horner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including unequal pupils, drooping of the left eyelid, and left shoulder and arm pain, suggest possible Horner's syndrome, which can result from a tumor in the chest. CT scan of the chest is the most appropriate next step in management to identify any potential tumor or abnormality. The other options mentioned are not relevant to the diagnosis of Horner's syndrome.
